He is the recipient of the first and third prizes of provincial and ministerial natural science and the second prize of municipal technological progress. He has hosted the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province. His research interests include functional nanostructures and energy science. Graphical abstract The application of modified transition metal telluride electrodes through (defect, compositing, and phase) engineering, including main cobalt telluride and (iron, nickel, zinc, copper, molybdenum, titanium) telluride in metal (Li, Na, K, Al)-ion batteries, lithium-sulfur and lithium-tellurium batteries, as well as aqueous zinc-ion batteries have been summarized. Metal (Li, Na, K, Al)-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur and lithium-tellurium batteries are gaining recognition for their eco-friendly characteristics, substantial energy density, and sustainable attributes. However, the overall performance of rechargeable batteries heavily depends on their electrode materials. Transition metal tellurides have recently gained significant attention due to their high electrical conductivity and density. Cobalt telluride has received the most extensive research due to its catalytic activity, unique magnetic properties, and diverse composition and crystal structure. Nevertheless, its limited conductivity and significant volume variation contribute to electrode structural deterioration and rapid capacity decline. This review comprehensively summarizes recent advances in rational design and synthesis of modified cobalt telluride-based electrodes, encompassing defect engineering (Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces) and composite engineering (derived carbon from precursors, carbon fibers, Mxene, graphene nanosheets, etc.). Particularly, the intricate evolution mechanisms of the conversion reaction process during cycling are elucidated. Furthermore, these modified strategies applied to other transitional metal tellurides, such as iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, molybdenum telluride, etc., are also thoroughly summarized. Additionally, their application extends to emerging aqueous zinc-ion batteries. Finally, potential challenges and prospects are discussed to further propel the development of transition metal tellurides electrode materials for next-generation rechargeable batteries. Keywords Rechargeable batteries Transition metal tellurides Cobalt telluride Defect engineering Composite engineering 1 Introduction In the context of the ongoing energy transition, the development of energy storage technologies has gained significant importance [1,2]. The efficiency and reliability of energy storage and release have become critical concerns, driven by the rapid growth and widespread adoption of renewable energy sources [3]. Rechargeable batteries, such as metal (Li, Na, K, Al)-ion and lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries, have garnered attention due to their environmentally friendly nature, high energy density, and sustainability [4–9]. However, the overall performance of rechargeable batteries heavily depends on their electrode material, which serves as the primary component [10]. In recent years, a range of transition metal-based electrode materials, including oxides, chalcogenides, and phosphides, have been reported due to their abundance and ability to facilitate multiple electron transfer processes [7,11–13]. Despite their potential, several challenges impede their progress, including inherent poor conductivity, limited ion storage capacity, and issues related to cycle stability caused by significant volume expansion or dissolution and shuttle effects of lithium polytellurides (LiPSs) in Li-S batteries [14–17]. Therefore, it is crucial to carefully select and design electrode materials that exhibit high conductivity, abundant active sites, and a stable structure to enhance power and energy density for improved battery applications. Transition metal tellurides (TMTs) have recently gained significant attention due to the unique characteristics of tellurium [18–21]. Tellurium (Te) exhibits higher electrical conductivity of approximately 2 × 102 S m−1, in contrast to selenium (Se) with a conductivity of about 1 × 10−4 S m−1, and sulfur (S) at approximately 5 × 10−16 S m−1 [22–26]. Additionally, Te has a high density (6.25 g cm−3), resulting in a high volumetric capacity (2625 mA h cm−3) [27–29]. Moreover, the lower electronegativity of Te leads to a higher degree of covalency in the metal–Te bonds, facilitating smooth electrochemical reactions [30–32]. Recent studies have reported the applications of various TMTs, including cobalt telluride, iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, and molybdenum telluride, in rechargeable batteries. Among them, cobalt telluride has received extensive research attention due to its catalytic activity, complex composition (CoTe2, CoTe, Co1+δTe) and crystal structure (hexagonal, orthorhombic, and rhombohedral) [33]. Li et al. successfully synthesized CoTe2 with hexagonal and orthorhombic phases by tellurization of Co single atoms onto N-doped graphene sheets at higher and lower temperatures, respectively [34,35]. It is found that the atomic arrangement and stacking of orthorhombic phase can be more effective to enhance the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs. In addition, the other advantages, such as high density (7.92 g cm−3), unique metallic characteristics, and magnetic properties, made it a competitive electrode material in metal (Li, Na, K, Al)-ion batteries [36–38]. However, the large volume variation and irreversible conversion reaction during cycles lead to the electrode structure deterioration and rapidly declining capacity. To achieve the full utilization of cobalt telluride electrodes, defect engineering (Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces) and composite (derived carbon from precursors, carbon fibers, Mxene, graphene nanosheets, etc.) engineering are the most effective and common modifying strategies. This comprehensive review summarizes recent advances in rational design and synthesis of modified cobalt telluride-based electrodes applied in metal ion batteries, Li-S batteries, and lithium-tellurium (Li-Te) batteries, encompassing defect engineering and composite engineering. Particularly, the intricate evolution mechanisms of the conversion reaction process during cycling are elucidated. Furthermore, these modified strategies applied to other TMTs, such as iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, molybdenum telluride, etc., are also thoroughly summarized. Additionally, their application extends to emerging aqueous zinc-ion batteries (AZIBs). Finally, potential challenges and prospects are discussed to further propel the development of transition metal telluride electrode materials for next-generation rechargeable batteries. 2 Modified cobalt telluride electrodes 2.1 The development of modified cobalt telluride electrodes The development process of modified cobalt telluride electrode is illustrated in Fig. 1 . Typically, in 2018, Zhang et al. first reported the application of CoTe2/graphene (GO) composites in sodium ion batteries (SIBs), demonstrating the formation of CoOC bonds between CoTe2 nanoparticles and GO, which facilitated enhanced cycling stability [36]. In 2020, Ganesan et al. utilized CoTe2-C nanocomposites (carbon derived from zeolitic imidazolate framework (ZIF-67)) as electrodes for both lithium ion batteries (LIBs) and SIBs, resulting in stable cycling performance up to 200 cycles due to the robust nature of the carbon matrix [39]. Yang et al. investigated the potassium storage capability of CoTe2, developing CoTe2-C microspheres (carbon derived from sucrose) as an anode with a stable discharge capacity of 189.5 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 after 100 cycles [40]. For the first application in aluminum-ion batteries (AIBs), Zhang et al. employed CoTe2@N-PC (carbon derived from ZIF-67) with uniformly dispersed orthorhombic CoTe2 nanoparticles on a porous carbon matrix as the cathode, effectively suppressing active material dissolution and achieving a high capacity even after 200 cycles [41]. In 2021, Xu et al. introduced Te vacancies in the orthorhombic phase CoTe2 and MXene composite through a P-doping strategy [42]. They observed decreased adsorption energy and diffusion barrier, increased potassium storage sites, and enhanced metallic characteristics compared to the composite without Te vacancies. Regarding the Li-S batteries, Song et al. discovered that N-doped CoTe2 has a strong binding capability with LiPSs through the formation of ionic Te–Li/N–Li bonds and covalent Co–S bonds [43]. In 2022, Co-vacancy defects were introduced into the composite of CoTe and nitrogen-doped carbon hollow nanoboxes (Cu-Co1− x Te@NC) using a copper-doping strategy. It was found that the presence of Co-vacancies strengthened the interaction between Cu-Co1− x Te and the NC framework and effectively reduced the diffusion barrier for lithium-ion transport [44]. Apart from vacancies, the construction of heterostructures has emerged as another effective strategy for accelerating reaction dynamics due to the built-in electric field. In 2022, Zhang et al. designed polyhedral shapes of ZnTe/CoTe2 heterojunctions distributed on an N-doped carbon shell, enabling the facile uptake and transport of potassium ions [45]. In comparison, homogeneous interfaces formed in polymorphic materials offer better compatibility. Later, Fan et al. constructed homogeneous phase interfaces (in hexagonal and orthorhombic forms) in CoTe2 to ensure robust and rapid ion storage [46]. In 2023, research on cobalt telluride in PIB and Li-S batteries has gained increasing attention [34]. On the other hand, the modifying strategies have also extended to other TMTs. 2.2 The application in organic metal ion batteries Cobalt telluride, employing the conversion reaction mechanism, emerges as a competitive anode material for organic alkali metal ion (Li+, Na+, K+) batteries. Upon discharge, it undergoes a transformation to yield metallic Co and the corresponding alkali metal telluride. During charging, the conversion reaction products can recombine to regenerate cobalt telluride. This intricate process involves multiple electron transfers, resulting in a high capacity. However, the significant volume variation throughout the process inevitably triggers structural collapse and rapid capacity decline. To overcome this challenge, recent advancements have focused on defect engineering (such as Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces) and composite engineering (involving carbon derived from precursors, carbon fibers, Mxene, graphene nanosheets, and more). These approaches have proven to be the most effective and widely adopted strategies for addressing this dilemma. 2.2.1 Defect engineering The common defects in alkali metal ion batteries are vacancies and interfaces. Introducing defect sites has been observed to modify the intrinsic electronic structure, expose more storage sites, enhance the adsorption energy for alkali metal ions, and reduce diffusion energy barriers. This facilitates high capacity and rapid charging capabilities [47–50]. Compared to vacancies, interfaces exhibit relatively higher stability, ensuring a certain degree of reaction reversibility. Moreover, interfaces generate an inherent electric field at their location, further enhancing the reaction dynamics [4,51–53]. The specific application of this strategy can be summarized as follows. 2.2.1.1 Vacancies Xu et al. reported a significant finding that P-doping induces the transformation of the hexagonal phase (h-CoTe2) (Fig. 2 a) to the orthorhombic phase (o-CoTe2) (Fig. 2b) in their study [42]. This transformation is accompanied by the generation of abundant Te vacancies. It is well-known that vacancy defects can act as potassium storage sites and contribute to additional capacity. However, maintaining the high capacity poses a challenge due to the poor structural stability during cycling. To address this issue, the researchers ingeniously combined the P-doping strategy with the composite approach using elastic Mxene. This combination effectively alleviates the enormous stress derived from volume expansion. Furthermore, they observed a strong interaction between the o-P-CoTe2 and MXene matrix, resulting in robust structural stability. The team performed density functional theory (DFT) calculations to gain insights into the adsorption and migration of potassium ions. The results showed that o-P-CoTe2/MXene exhibited significantly lower adsorption energy (E ad) and diffusion barrier than h-CoTe2 and h-CoTe2/MXene (Fig. 2c and d). Additionally, o-P-CoTe2/MXene displayed a stronger metallic characteristic (Fig. 2e), as evidenced by a more continuous electronic state at the Fermi level. Because of these favorable properties, the o-P-CoTe2/MXene superstructure demonstrated impressive performance. It exhibited a high reversible capacity of 373.7 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 after 200 cycles (Fig. 2f) and remarkable rate capability, achieving 168.2 mA h g−1 at 20 A g−1 (Fig. 2g). Cation vacancies possess similar characteristics to typical anion vacancies, allowing them to finely tune the electronic structure, provide additional active sites, and reduce diffusion energy barriers [54–56]. However, the utilization of cation vacancies in electrode materials remains uncommon due to the scarcity of suitable host materials [57–59]. In a recent breakthrough, Hu et al. creatively induced Co-vacancy defects in CoTe through a copper-doping strategy involving chemical etching and subsequent tellurization [44]. To further enhance performance, the defected CoTe was ingeniously encapsulated within nitrogen-doped carbon hollow nanoboxes (Fig. 3 a–c), forming Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs. Remarkably, the existence of Co-vacancies in Cu-Co1− x Te@NC strengthens the interaction between Cu-Co1− x Te and the NC framework, as evidenced by the positive shift in the binding energy of Co 2p and the negative shift of N 1s (Fig. 3d and e). Moreover, DFT calculations provided a more intuitive view of the increased electron accumulation around NC in Cu-Co1− x Te@NC compared to only partial electron accumulation in CoTe@NC (Fig. 3f). This strong electron transfer from Co to N signifies an enhanced combination between Cu-Co1− x Te and NC. Additionally, the p-band center of Cu-Co1− x Te@NC was found to move further away from the Fermi level compared to CoTe@NC, indicating a robust adhesion of bonding states between Cu-Co1− x Te and NC (Fig. 3g), which greatly contribute to the nanostructural stability. Furthermore, introducing Co-vacancies effectively reduces the diffusion barrier for lithium-ion transport (Fig. 3h). Consequently, when employed as anodes for LIB, the as-prepared Cu-Co1− x Te@NC HNBs exhibited exceptional long-term cycling stability (>800 cycles) and superior rate performance (365 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1), as shown in Fig. 3(i). 2.2.1.2 Heterointerface In addition to vacancies, constructing heterostructures is another highly effective strategy for accelerating reaction dynamics [60–63]. This approach involves the formation of atomic-level heterogeneous interfaces between materials with various work functions. As a result, an inherent electric field is generated, facilitating a significant enhancement in charge transfer [64–66]. A crucial advantage of such heterostructures lies in their inherent stability, which guarantees, to a certain extent, the reversibility of the reactions. Firstly, Zhang et al. designed polyhedral shapes of ZnTe/CoTe2 heterojunctions distributed on N-doped carbon shell, achieving the ready uptake and transport of potassium ions due to the enhanced electronic conductivity contributed by the significant hybridization band of ZnTe/CoTe2 [45]. Subsequently, Pan et al. fabricated a CoTe2/ZnTe heterostructure by anchoring it onto MXene (CZT) (Fig. 4 a and b) through tellurization of CoZn-MOF onto Ti3C2T x MXene [67]. They employed DFT calculations to determine the band structures, DOS, adsorption energy of K+, and migration energy barriers for both the CoTe2/ZnTe heterostructure and the individual phases. The results revealed that the CoTe2/ZnTe heterostructure exhibited a metallic energy band structure, which differed significantly from the semiconducting characteristics of CoTe2 and ZnTe. Moreover, the CoTe2/ZnTe heterostructure demonstrated lower adsorption energy (Fig. 4c) and migration energy barriers (Fig. 4d) than its corresponding single phase. The researchers also calculated the charge density differences at the heterogeneous interface and the work functions of CoTe2/ZnTe, indicating the presence of a built-in electric field directed from the ZnTe side to the CoTe2 side due to the lower work functions of ZnTe (Fig. 4e). The metallic conductivity, improved K+ adsorption, facilitated K+ migration path, and the additional driving force originating from the built-in electric field collectively contributed to the accelerated reaction kinetics and excellent rate capabilities of CZT, achieving a capacity of 137.0 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1. Furthermore, the CZT electrodes demonstrated exceptional structural stability, retaining a capacity of 175.3 mA h g−1 after 4000 cycles at 3.0 A g−1. Diverging from the conventional polyhedron Zn/Co-ZIF-67 precursors, Jiang et al. successfully synthesized two-dimensional (2D) iris petal-like CoZn-ZIFs precursors through a facile co-precipitation reaction [68]. Through a one-step tellurization process, CoTe2-ZnTe heterostructures were formed, accompanied by the development of nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) that retained the original petal morphology (Fig. 5 a). CoTe2-ZnTe nanoparticles were uniformly anchored on both sides of the NC skeleton, creating abundant phase boundaries within the heterostructure (Fig. 5b). This unique configuration introduced a substantial number of defects and active sites, thereby enhancing electron/ionic diffusion kinetics and overall stability. The immediate impact of these modifications is evident from the differential capacity versus voltage (dQ/dV) diagrams and heat maps of the dQ/dV profiles of the two samples. Specifically, the CoZn-Te/NC electrode exhibited a negligible loss in the intensity of redox peaks from the 15th to 88th cycle (Fig. 5c), while the CoTe2/NC electrode experienced continuous degradation (Fig. 5d), attributed to the partial irreversible conversion reaction of CoTe2. Furthermore, laser confocal scanning microscopy (LCSM) was employed to observe the surface of the electrodes before and after cycling (Fig. 5e). Prior to cycling, both electrodes displayed smooth surfaces. However, after 80 cycles, the CoTe2/NC electrode exhibited noticeable fluctuations in altitude compared to the CoZn-Te/NC electrode, indicating the superior structural stability of the CoZn-Te/NC anodes. Molybdenum ditelluride (MoTe2) is a representative van der Waals material with a relatively large spacing of 0.69 nm in the (002) crystal plane, which is crucial for stable potassium storage. Zeng et al. demonstrated the feasibility of forming a heterojunction with CoTe2 by calculating the more negative adsorption energy of K atom (−2.23 eV) for CoTe2/MoTe2, which is lower than that of −1.65 eV for CoTe2 and 2.38 eV for pristine MoTe2 (Fig. 5f). Furthermore, they fabricated a CoTe2/MoTe2 heterojunction encapsulated by an “inner” NC framework and an “outer” reduced graphene oxide (rGO) (Fig. 5g and h), denoted as MCT-NC@rGO [69]. Thanks to the buffer space provided by the hetero-interface and the carbon coating, the MCT-NC@rGO anode exhibited outstanding cycling stability, achieving a capacity of 160 mA h g−1 over 2000 cycles at 1.0 A g−1. The superb structural stability of this configuration was confirmed by in-situ TEM. Upon potassiation for 100 s, the initial triangular nanosheet with a width of approximately 147.6 nm increased to 151.1 nm, representing only about 2.37% of the original width. During the reverse process, the nanosheet gradually recovered its size, reaching 147.9 nm upon complete depotassiation (Fig. 5i). 2.2.1.3 Homogeneous interfaces Compared to heterogeneous interfaces between two different materials, which often have larger lattice mismatches, homogeneous interfaces in polymorphic materials offer better compatibility [70–72]. Therefore, constructing homogeneous phase interfaces represents another effective strategy to ensure robust and rapid ion storage [73,74]. In the field of ion storage, phase junctions have been successfully utilized in materials such as GeO2, CoSe2, and Nb2O5, demonstrating accelerated reaction kinetics and excellent stability over multiple cycles [12,73,75,76]. Fan et al. discovered that submicron-sized rod-like CoTe2, coated uniformly with carbon, can exist in hexagonal and orthorhombic forms (o/h-CoTe2) [46]. Notably, o/h-CoTe2 exhibits the highest capacity of 438 mA h g−1 at a high current density of 1 C after 400 cycles, surpassing the hexagonal or orthorhombic phases. Importantly, the phase content can be precisely tuned by controlling the amount of carbon coating. As the carbon content increases, the corresponding hexagonal phase content decreases. When the hexagonal phase content reaches 44%, the composite demonstrates optimal electrochemical performance [46]. In summary, the key findings of existing research on the application of defect engineering (including Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces) in organic metal ion batteries have been outlined above. It is evident that defect engineering plays a pivotal role in creating additional reaction sites and expediting the transport of electrons/ions. However, the research focuses on the composite of cobalt telluride, such as its combination with MXene and various nitrogen-doped carbon materials, which may not facilitate the fabrication of electrodes with high energy density. Furthermore, the precise impact of defect engineering on structural stability throughout cycles remains to be accurately delineated. Hence, there is a pressing need to obtain pure cobalt telluride, which can also find applications in other domains, including water splitting, dye-sensitized solar cells, and oxygen reduction reactions. 2.2.2 Compositing engineering The combination of CoTe2 and carbon effectively enhances the cycling stability for organic alkali-ion batteries, providing a high-conductivity buffer space. CoTe2 nanoparticles embedded within a carbon matrix can be directly obtained through either a two-step or one-step tellurization process of a metal–organic framework (MOF). One commonly used metal–organic framework is the ZIF-67, which exhibits a polyhedral morphology. Ganesan et al. initially carbonized ZIF-67 to obtain CoC, and subsequently tellurized CoC to form a CoTe2-C nanocomposite [39]. The resulting CoTe2-C nanocomposite inherits the polyhedral morphology of ZIF-67 (Fig. 6 a), with CoTe2 nanocrystallites ranging from 3 to 6 nm uniformly dispersed within the carbon matrix (Fig. 6b). When utilized as electrodes in both LIB and SIB, the CoTe2-C electrodes exhibited significant initial reversible capacities of 500 and 323 mA h g−1, respectively, along with stable cycling performance for up to 200 cycles. This stable performance can be attributed to the robust nature of the carbon matrix, which effectively accommodates the strain generated by the conversion and recombination processes of CoTe2. The robust role of the carbon matrix is supported by ex-situ HR-TEM images of the CoTe2-C electrodes after 20 Li/Na-cycles (Fig. 6c and e) and 50 Li/Na-cycles (Fig. 6d and f), where the polyhedral morphology is well-preserved, and the size of the CoTe2 nanocrystallites exhibits minimal change. In another study conducted by Sarkar et al., a one-step tellurization process was employed to produce a composite material (CoTe@NCD) consisting of hexagonal phase cobalt telluride and nitrogen-rich carbon [77]. This was achieved through the Te melt infiltration of ZIF-67 at 900 °C. The resulting microstructure exhibited a dodecahedral morphology, with 86 wt% CoTe nanoparticles (measuring 21 nm) embedded within a porous carbon matrix (Fig. 6g). This unique architecture renders the CoTe@NCD hybrid an ideal candidate for anode materials in potassium and sodium ion storage applications. Jiang et al. subsequently coordinated ZIF-67 with rGO and directly tellurized the composite precursors, forming CoTe2@3DG [78]. This composite consisted of an orthorhombic CoTe2 phase encapsulated by a hollow carbon polyhedron and a graphene network (Fig. 6h). The double confined effect of the hybrids led to superior sodium storage capabilities, particularly in terms of rate performance, surpassing other reported tellurides. Hu et al. successfully utilized CNT as an alternative composite material with ZIF-67, achieving the bridging of CoTe2 polyhedra through tellurization of the composite precursors (Fig. 6i) [79]. Incorporating interwoven CNTs significantly enhanced the electronic conductivity of CoTe2@CNTs near the Fermi level. Consequently, the CoTe2@CNT composites exhibited exceptional sodium storage capacities, maintaining a capacity of 112.7 mA h g−1 at 2 A g−1 after 500 cycles. GO possesses a large surface area and abundant oxygen-containing groups [80–82], making it an excellent support material for loading various metal compounds. Zhang et al. synthesized a CoTe2/GO composite (Fig. 7 a) using a solvothermal method, where the CoTe2 nanoparticles formed CoOC bonds with graphene [36]. Due to the strong interfacial interaction in the composite and the high density of bulk CoTe2 (7.92 g cm−3), the CoTe2/GO exhibits a high gravimetric capacity of 647.9 mA h cm−3 after 100 cycle at 0.05 A g−1. In another study, Zhou et al. prepared CoTe2 quantum-rods encapsulated by rGO and NC (CoTe2@rGO@NC) (Fig. 7b) through a hydrothermal method followed by carbonization [35]. The dual physicochemical confinement of the CoTe2@rGO@NC electrode resulted in superior rate performance, with a capacity of 106.7 mA h g−1 at 2.0 A g−1. It was observed that the quantum-rod morphology could be well preserved after the initial fully charged state (Fig. 7c), which correlated with the superior electrochemical performance. Interestingly, during the first fully discharged state, the quantum rod morphology transformed into nano-rods (∼40 nm) (Fig. 7d), warranting further in-depth investigation. Typically, the composite of carbon and CoTe2 can be prepared simultaneously through a one-step tellurization process of carefully designed precursors. These precursors can be obtained using either electrospinning or template methods. Zhang et al. fabricated a stabilized PAN/PS/Co(ac)2·4H2O film via electrospinning, which could be transformed into CoTe2 nanoparticles embedded in freestanding N-doped multichannel carbon fibers (CoTe2@NMCNFs) (Fig. 7e) through subsequent tellurization [83]. When the CoTe2@NMCNFs electrode was applied in SIBs, it demonstrated excellent cyclability, as evidenced by the well-preserved fibrous morphology observed in ex-TEM analysis (Fig. 7f). Furthermore, the pseudocapacitive-dominated behavior of CoTe2@NMCNFs enabled high-rate performance, achieving a capacity of 152.4 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1 (Fig. 7g). Zhao et al. designed a hierarchical dual-type carbon to confine the CoTe2 nanocrystals (Fig. 7h), namely CoTe2@3DPNC [84]. The inner carbon scaffold existed in a three-dimensional (3D) porous carbon matrix form synthesized by a NaCl-template method with citric acid as carbon source. In comparison, the outer carbon mesh is derived from the pyrolysis of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP), accompanied by the generation of CoTe2 nanocrystals. The hierarchical carbon matrix can offer a robust and fast ion/electronic conductive pathway for sodium storage, thus the CoTe2@3DPNC exhibited reliable rate performance (Fig. 7i), with a capacity of 164.2 mA h g−1 (476.2 mA h cm−3) at 5.0 A g−1, accompanied by the high capacitive contribution with 88.1% at 2.0 mV s−1. In addition to its applications in LIBs, SIBs, and potassium ion batteries (PIBs), CoTe2 and carbon composites have also been explored for AIBs by Zhang et al. [41]. They synthesized CoTe2@N-PC by calcining a mixture of ZIF-67 nanocrystals and pure tellurium powder at 500 °C for 12 h. The resulting composite exhibited a unique microstructure with uniformly dispersed orthorhombic CoTe2 nanoparticles on a porous carbon matrix. This structure effectively suppressed active material dissolution, enabling CoTe2@N-PC to achieve a high capacity of 635.8 mA h g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 even after 200 cycles. Ex-situ XPS analysis revealed that both Te and Co served as redox sites during charging, with Te transforming Te(II) to Te(0) and Te(II) to Te(IV), while Co changed from Co(II) to Co(III). The discharging process was reversible, although partial Co(III) reduction was observed. Compared to defect engineering, research on composite engineering is considerably more extensive. Various carbon materials, ranging from single components (e.g., ZIF-67 derived carbon, GO, NMCNFs) to dual components (e.g., ZIF-67 derived carbon/rGO, rGO/NC, citric acid and PVP derived carbon), have been investigated. Moreover, the interaction between the carbon matrix and cobalt telluride particles has also been revealed. However, the depth of research in composite engineering remains insufficient. In the future, single doping of elements such as B, F, P, S, or multiple doping in carbon can be pursued to further enhance the electrochemical performance of composites. Additionally, finite element analysis and DFT calculations need to be incorporated to aid in the design of electrodes and analyze the underlying reaction mechanisms. For instance, the carbon buffer effects on strain/stress during cycles can be intuitively reflected through Comsol simulations, and the critical role of doping atoms in carbon on intermediate or final reaction products, such as K5Te3, K2Te, Na2Te, can be elucidated through DFT calculations. 2.3 The application in Li-S battery Li-S batteries, utilizing sulfur as the cathode, have attracted significant research interest due to their potential for achieving a high energy density of up to 2600 W h kg−1 [85–87]. During discharge, the solid-phase sulfur dissolves into the electrolyte and is gradually reduced to Li2S, undergoing phase transformations from Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, and Li2S2, ultimately forming Li2S [88,89]. Throughout this multi-step reaction process, soluble LiPSs can migrate to the anode, leading to the corrosion of the lithium anode and causing irreversible capacity loss. Additionally, the sulfur electrode suffers from low electron/ion conductivity, resulting in a low utilization rate, poor rate capacity, and stability [90,91]. Recent studies have revealed that defective cobalt telluride electrodes or specific phases or cobalt telluride composites, serving as interlayer, hosts, or separator modifiers, can effectively immobilize LiPSs and suppress the shuttle effect, thereby enhancing the multi-step redox reaction, achieving the practical application of Li-S batteries. 2.3.1 Defect engineering Defects engineering in Li-S batteries has played a crucial role by serving as adsorption and catalytic sites for immobilizing and converting various intermediates, thanks to the precise control of atomic distributions and electronic structures. Taking advantage of these benefits, defects such as heteroatom doping and vacancies in materials are anticipated to create abundant localized electrons, thereby enhancing charge transfer, ion diffusion, and adsorption. As a result, they are expected to serve as promising anchoring and catalytic sites for LiPSs, effectively inhibiting the shuttle effect and improving capacity retention in Li-S batteries [92,93]. Song et al. discovered that N-doped CoTe2 could fulfill this role by simultaneously forming ionic TeLi/NLi bonding and covalent CoS bonding to bind LiPSs strongly. Specifically, they introduced N-doping in CoTe2 nanotube (CoTe2-N) by annealing it at 350 °C in ammonia and utilized it as an interlayer for LiS batteries. It can deliver impressive rate capability (758 mA h g−1 at 4 C) and superb high capacity (1105 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C after 100 cycles). The underlying mechanism of LiPSs adsorption on CoTe2-N and CoTe2 can be elucidated through DFT calculations. Compared to CoTe2, CoTe2-N exhibits higher adsorption energies (Fig. 8 a) to all sulfur species due to the enhanced Co–S interaction and the formation of NLi bonds, resulting in a higher LiPSs binding capability. Furthermore, the formation of ionic TeLi and NLi bonds and the covalent CoS bonding is intuitively evidenced by the electron localization function (ELF) of CoTe2-N (Fig. 8b). It is important to note that terminal sulfur (ST) is preferred for coordination with Co due to its more negative electrostatic potential (Fig. 8c) compared to bridging sulfur (SB). Additionally, the electrostatic potential difference (Fig. 8d) between CoTe2 and CoTe2-N reveals that N-doping alters the electronic properties of Co, thereby improving the sulfiphilicity of the Co site. Remarkably, these calculation results provide strong evidence for the enhanced dual-anchoring property of CoTe2-N. Cheng et al. introduced Te into CoTe2/rGO and conducted an adsorption test in a Li2S6 solution for 24 h [94]. In the presence of CoTe2/rGO and Te-CoTe2/rGO, the fading of the solution colors and the disappearance of the Li2S6 adsorption peak were clearly observed (Fig. 8e), indicating the critical role of CoTe2 in the absorption of LiPSs. Furthermore, the conversion kinetics process of rGO, CoTe2/rGO, and Te-CoTe2/rGO to LiPSs was investigated using cyclic voltammetry (CV). It was found that the Te-CoTe2/rGO electrode exhibited the lowest absolute values of the response voltage for both the oxidation and reduction processes (Fig. 8f), providing evidence for its effective catalytic conversion of Li2S6. Potentiostatic discharge profiles for these electrodes revealed that the Te-CoTe2/rGO electrode exhibited the shortest response time (124 ± 4 s) and the highest peak current (1.9 ± 0.1 mA) (Fig. 8g), further indicating the significant advantage of Te-CoTe2/rGO in catalyzing the LiPSs conversion reaction. Interestingly, it was discovered that the presence of Te could better protect the lithium anode in Li-S batteries by facilitating the formation of Li2Te x S y (Fig. 8h) through the reaction of Te0 and Li2S6. In the presence of Li2Te x S y , the symmetric battery maintained a stable voltage of approximately 27 mV over 600 h (Fig. 8i, j), exhibiting a smooth voltage platform. Huang et al. pioneered the integration of defect and heterojunction engineering strategies in the context of Li-S batteries to explore their compatibility and potential synergistic effects [75]. They synthesized and investigated two types of NC-based composites containing ZnTe/CoTe2 heterostructures, one with Te-vacancies (v-ZnTe/CoTe2) and another without Te-vacancies (ZnTe/CoTe2), as catalysts. DFT calculations revealed that ZnTe/CoTe2 and v-ZnTe/CoTe2 exhibited a continuous conduction band with a significant total DOS at the Fermi level (Fig. 8k), indicating excellent conductivity. Furthermore, the d band center of v-ZnTe/CoTe2 was observed to shift closer to the Fermi level compared to pure ZnTe/CoTe2, facilitating increased electron occupancy in the antibonding orbital between the sulfur species and the metal. This phenomenon further enhanced the adsorption of LiPSs and the deposition of Li2S. Bader charge analysis (Fig. 8l–o) demonstrated that v-ZnTe/CoTe2 exhibited greater charge transfer (0.87 additional electrons) from ZnTe to CoTe2, which can accelerate Li+ diffusion and electron transport. Additionally, the calculated binding energies to LiPSs for v-ZnTe/CoTe2 were higher (Fig. 8p) than those for ZnTe/CoTe2. The improved adsorption of LiPSs and enhanced Li+ transportation capabilities of v-ZnTe/CoTe2 resulted in remarkable rate capability with high specific capacities at all current densities. In summary, defect-engineered modifications of cobalt telluride, through doping or creating Te vacancies, effectively catalyze the conversion of LiPSs, either by acting as interlayers or hosts. N doping has been observed to alter the electronic properties of cobalt, thereby enhancing the sulfiphilicity of cobalt sites, while Te vacancies shift the d-band center closer to the Fermi level, resulting in increased adsorption energy towards LiPSs. The aforementioned research is significant as it lays the foundation for further exploration into the crucial roles of non-metallic elements (B, F, P, S) and metallic elements (Fe, Cu, Ni, Zn) doping, as well as investigating Te or Co vacancies in pure cobalt telluride without composite materials. 2.3.2 Phase engineering The diverse intrinsic crystal structures give rise to variations in electronic, mechanical, and catalytic properties [95]. Variances in atomic arrangement and stacking models of catalytic host materials invariably influence the adsorption and conversion of LiPSs. Nonetheless, exploring the relationship between crystal phases and catalytic activity in Li–S batteries is still relatively limited. Depending on the synthetic conditions, cobalt ditellurides can exhibit two polymorphs: orthorhombic (o−) and hexagonal (h−) CoTe2. Recently, Li et al. successfully synthesized nanocrystalline CoTe2 onto N-doped graphene sheets (CoTe2/NG) by tellurization of Co single atoms on NG [34]. The phase composition was found to be controllable through the tellurization temperature, where lower and higher temperatures resulted in the formation of o-CoTe2 and h-CoTe2 phases, respectively. Importantly, the researchers demonstrated that o-CoTe2 is an effective catalyst for promoting the conversion of LiPSs, as supported by both DFT calculations and experimental evidence. Initially, the researchers investigated the interaction of NG, h-CoTe2, and o-CoTe2 with sulfur species. They found that o-CoTe2 exhibited the strongest binding ability to various sulfur species (Fig. 9 a), indicating its effective capture of LiPSs and suppression of the shuttle effect. This strong adsorption strength of o-CoTe2 can be attributed to the higher d-band centers of Co atoms on o-CoTe2 than that of h-CoTe2 (−1.11 eV vs. −1.54 eV) after absorbing Li2S (Fig. 9b and c). These higher d-band centers correspond to the location of higher antibonding orbitals, lower occupation, and stronger interaction between o-CoTe2 and Li2S. In addition, 3D electron density difference diagrams and Bader charge analysis (Fig. 9d) demonstrated a higher charge conversion from Li2S to o-CoTe2 compared to NG and h-CoTe2, further confirming the strong interaction between Li2S and o-CoTe2. This strong interaction leads to a decrease in Li–S bond energy and an increase in bond length, facilitating the decomposition of Li2S. The lower energy barrier (Fig. 9e) for Li2S decomposition along the o-CoTe2 surface provides additional evidence for its catalytic activity. Moreover, ELF analysis (Fig. 9f) revealed a highly delocalized charge between Li and S for o-CoTe2 with the adsorption of Li2S2, promoting the transformation from Li2S2 to Li2S. Finally, the lowest Li+ diffusion barrier (Fig. 9g) for o-CoTe2 indicated its favorable diffusion of Li+. Therefore, o-CoTe2 exhibited superior catalytic behavior compared to h-CoTe2. Experimental results confirmed the efficient capture of Li2S6 by o-CoTe2/NG, as evidenced by the obvious color fading of the Li2S6 electrolyte and the disappearance of the Li2S6 adsorption peak after 10 h of mixing (Fig. 9h). Furthermore, potentiostatic discharge profiles at 2.05 V revealed that the o-CoTe2/NG electrode exhibited the shortest nucleation time (237 s) and the highest precipitation capacity of Li2S (547 mA h g−1) (Fig. 9i), indicating its enhanced performance in Li2S deposition. On the Li anode side, it was observed that o-CoTe2 displayed a higher E ad (2.22 eV) for Li atoms compared to h-CoTe2 (1.20 eV), enabling controllable Li deposition (Fig. 9j). In comparison to h-CoTe2/NG@Li symmetric batteries, the o-CoTe2/NG@Li counterpart demonstrated stable lithium stripping/plating for over 950 h with a lower overpotential of 15 mV at 2 mA cm−2 and 2 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 9k). The full cell assembled using o-CoTe2/NG as the host for both electrodes owned exceptional cycling stability at 0.5C for 800 cycles, with a minimal capacity decay of only 0.055% per cycle. The aforementioned investigation demonstrates that o-CoTe2 performs superiorly as a catalyst in mitigating the shuttle effect of LiPSs when contrasted with h-CoTe2. Nonetheless, cobalt telluride can manifest in diverse compositions (CoTe2, CoTe, Co1+δTe) and crystal structures (hexagonal, orthorhombic, and rhombohedral). Hence, future endeavors could focus on comparative analyses of these cobalt tellurides, elucidating their respective catalytic mechanisms and identifying the optimal host materials. 2.3.3 Compositing engineering Due to their unique 2D structure, high conductivity, and robust mechanical strength, MXene and GO are frequently used as composites with transition metal compounds [96]. This enhances the electrode conductivity and buffers the volumetric variation of sulfur during electrochemical reactions, which can synergistically satisfy the specific demands of Li–S batteries [97]. The use of hexagonal CoTe in Li–S batteries has recently gained significant research attention due to its metallic characteristics. Ye et al. successfully fabricated a CoTe-MXene composite through a one-step solvothermal method, where one-dimensional CoTe nanorods were uniformly dispersed on a 2D MXene sheet (Fig. 10 a) [98]. CV profiles of symmetric cells using CoTe-MXene demonstrated distinct staged peaks and higher peak current responses than those of MXene and CoTe alone (Fig. 10b). These results indicated the accelerated conversion kinetics of LiPSs facilitated by the CoTe-MXene catalyst. Furthermore, the CoTe-MXene catalyst exhibited the lowest activation energy (E a) among these catalysts (Fig. 10c), providing strong evidence for the rapid conversion from Li2S4 to Li2S. When employed as a separator modifier under high-temperature conditions (60 °C), the Li-S batteries incorporating the CoTe-MXene modified separator demonstrated excellent rate capability, achieving a remarkable capacity of 905 mA h g−1 at 3 C (Fig. 10d). Even under conditions of limited electrolyte volume (4 μL mg−1), the CoTe-MXene modified separator still maintained an impressive areal capacity of 4.0 mA h cm−2 after 50 cycles (Fig. 10e). These findings clearly demonstrate the superior thermal stability and high sulfur utilization of the CoTe-MXene modified separator. The modified CoTe catalyst can serve as a bi-functionally integrated host, effectively addressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs and suppressing the growth of lithium dendrites. Li et al. developed an NC matrix consisting of one-dimensional (1D) carbon nanotubes (CNT) and 2D GO to support CoTe nanocrystals (CoTe ⊂ NCGs) (Fig. 10f) through in-situ embedding [99]. Notably, the S@CoTe ⊂ NCGs exhibited a significantly higher exchange current density (Fig. 10g) than S@NC, indicating the remarkable efficiency of sulfur species conversion. Moreover, the CoTe ⊂ NCGs displayed highly lithiophilic properties, as evidenced by their calculated high adsorption energy (Fig. 10h) towards lithium atoms. Consequently, the CoTe ⊂ NCGs@Cu composite exhibited an impressive Coulombic efficiency (CE) of nearly 100% over 100 cycles at a current density of 2 mA cm−2 (Fig. 10i). The aforementioned studies extend the application of CoTe at high temperatures through its composite with MXene. Additionally, by incorporating 1D CNTs and 2D GO into the composite, the modified CoTe effectively suppresses the growth of lithium dendrites. However, the scope of this research is limited, necessitating further efforts such as exploring other cobalt telluride composites (e.g., CoTe2 and Co1+δTe) and enhancing the electrochemical performance of these composites for use in low-temperature conditions. 2.4 The application in Li-Te battery The Li-Te battery, as a new energy storage system, has sparked research enthusiasm due to its similar reaction mechanism to Li-S batteries, high volumetric capacity of 2621 mA h cm−3, and high conductivity up to 2 × 102 S m−1. However, the issues related to the shuttle effect of lithium polytellurides (LiPTs) need to be addressed. Inspired by the application of metal sulfides in Li-S batteries, metal tellurides are considered ideal host materials for tellurium. However, there is a lack of experimental or theoretical reports on metal tellurides. Recently, Wang et al. conducted DFT calculations to screen the most suitable cathode material from seven types of metal tellurides (CoTe2, NbTe2, NiTe2, TiTe2, VTe2, MoTe2, WTe2) [100]. The calculations included E ad and conversion capability of LiPTs, as well as diffusion energy barriers of Li ions. The results revealed that CoTe2, NbTe2, NiTe2, TiTe2, and VTe2 preferentially exist in the 1T configuration, while MoTe2 and WTe2 exhibit a preferable 2H phase configuration. Metal tellurides with the 1T phase, particularly CoTe2 and NbTe2, exhibit stronger E ad compared to the 2H phase (Fig. 11 a), which can effectively inhibit the dissolution of LiPTs. To illustrate this, the authors analyzed the difference in charge density and Bader charge between Li2Te8 adsorbed on 1T phase (CoTe2 and NbTe2) and 2H phase (MoTe2 and WTe2) host materials (Fig. 11b). The analysis indicated intimate chemical adsorption between Li2Te8 and the 1T phase, characterized by significant electron transfer from the 1T phase to Li2Te8. This chemical interaction is further supported by the shift of the DOS image to the low-energy region (Fig. 11c). On the other hand, only physical adsorption occurs in the 2H phase without noticeable electron transfer and DOS shift (Fig. 11d). Furthermore, the authors calculated the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for each reaction coordinate (Fig. 11e) and found that CoTe2 exhibits the lowest ΔG for the potential-determining step (ΔG p), indicating the ease of conversion reaction for CoTe2. It is important to note that both excessively strong and weak LiPTs adsorption are unfavorable for further conversion reactions. For example, NbTe2 exhibits excessively strong E ad to Li2Te4, hindering its desorption and resulting in a high ΔG (Fig. 11f). The authors proposed a volcanic relationship plot of E ad-Li2Te4 and ΔG p (Fig. 11g) as a guideline for selecting suitable cathode materials. Finally, CoTe2 demonstrates high binding energies to Li ions (Fig. 11h), second only to NbTe2. The DOS of CoTe2 after binding a Li-ion exhibits a bandgap of 0.00 eV (Fig. 11i), and the peak value at the Fermi energy level decreases, indicating the stability of the configuration after Li-ion adsorption. Additionally, CoTe2 exhibits lower diffusion activation energy along the middle of the two Te atoms. Therefore, CoTe2 may be the most suitable cathode material for Li-Te batteries. Theoretical feasibility may prompt future endeavors in synthesizing cobalt telluride catalysts for high-performance Li-Te batteries. 2.5 Analysis of the conversion reaction process To achieve excellent cycling performance at various current densities, research in rechargeable batteries usually focuses on modifying the material, such as particle nanosizing, structural engineering, and defect engineering. However, there is a lack of research on the in-depth analysis of the conversion reaction due to limited characterization technologies. The limited reports, including exploring the transfornation of intermediates, the reaction mechanism post conversion reaction, and evolution and stability of conversion reaction products of heterostructure are summarized as follows. 2.5.1 The transformation of intermediates Recently, Li et al. made an important discovery regarding the critical role of the N atom's existence form in carbon [101]. They designed three samples: CoTe2@PCNFs (porous carbon nanofibers), CoTe2@NPCNFs (N-doping PCNFs), and CoTe2@NPCNFs@NC (N-doping PCNFs and N-doped porous carbon). Through their investigation, they found that the dual-type N-doped carbon-confined CoTe2 composite material exhibits excellent electrochemical performance. The researchers elucidated the typical “intercalation-conversion” mechanism during potassiation by employing in situ XRD, Raman spectroscopy measurements, and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), as well as ex-situ XPS and TEM. In a creative approach, the dissolution of polytelluride intermediates was intuitively observed and reflected through in situ UV–vis absorption. Measurements of the three samples revealed that compared to CoTe2@NPCNFs and CoTe2@PCNFs, which exhibited stronger absorption intensities and lower wavelength shifts during discharging (Fig. 12 b, c), CoTe2@NPCNFs@NC showed slightly stronger intensities and nearly no shift in absorption location (Fig. 12a). Meanwhile, the color variation of the CoTe2@NPCNFs@NC electrode showed only slight changes (Fig. 12d), unlike the pronounced color variation observed in the electrolyte for CoTe2@NPCNFs and CoTe2@PCNFs (Fig. 12e, f). These results strongly suggest that the dual-type N-doped carbon layer effectively prevents the dissolution and shuttle reaction of LiPTs. This prevention can be attributed to the strong interaction between LiPTs and the N-doped dual-type porous carbon skeleton. This theory is further supported by DFT calculations, which revealed that the E ad of K5Te3 and K2Te on N-doped substrates (Fig. 12g), particularly pyrrolic-N, exhibited more negative values compared to graphene substrates. Moreover, the electron density differences indicated the transfer of electrons from K5Te3 and K2Te clusters to carbon substrates, particularly the N-sites. Furthermore, the nudged elastic band (NEB) calculations demonstrated that the N-doping could further facilitate the transformation of K5Te3 to other K-rich polytellurides. As a result, the CoTe2@NPCNFs@NC anode exhibits fast reaction kinetics and excellent electrochemical performance. 2.5.2 Reaction mechanism post conversion reaction For the additional capacity contribution for the ferromagnetic metal compound anodes beyond the conversion reaction, Li et al. revealed the interface magnetization mechanism adopting in situ magnetometry [37]. Building upon this, Fan et al. observed a gradual enhancement of interface magnetization phenomenon during cycles for CoTe2 nanoparticles (15–25 nm) with a thin carbon layer encapsulation on an N-doping carbon (50–120 nm) substrate, leading to the achievement of ultra-high capacity [37]. They initially employed in situ EIS measurements to explore the possible reaction mechanism following the conversion reaction. They extracted the charge transfer resistance (R ct) value during discharge from 2.56 to 0.2 V (Fig. 13 a–c), revealing a slight change in R ct from 2.56 to 1.84 V due to the initial insertion process of lithium ions. Upon further discharge to 1.01 V, the R ct decreased, indicating the conversion reaction of CoTe2 to Co and Li2Te. Interestingly, they observed a gradual increase in R ct within the 0.91–0.2 V range, which could be attributed to the movement of spin-down electrons to the surface layer of Co nanoparticles. Furthermore, the lithiation electrode after one cycle was examined using HAADF-STEM imaging and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) mapping (Fig. 13d and e), demonstrating the orderly distribution of refined nanoparticles (about 3 nm) on the carbon substrates. After 150 cycles, the size of CoTe2 nanoparticles decreased to <1 nm (Fig. 13f and g). The reduction in particle size resulted in a larger interface contact area, offering greater capacity through interface magnetization. Consequently, the discharge capacity contributed by interface magnetization (from 0.8 to 0.01 V) increased from the initial 448 mA h g−1 to 581 and 652 mA h g−1 after 50 and 100 cycles, respectively. Moreover, the charge capacity contributed by interface magnetization in the range of 0.01–1.75 V also continuously increased with cycles (Fig. 13h). Additionally, the positively shifted reduction peak location during cycling (Fig. 13i) and the high pseudocapacitive contribution ratio (81.4% at 1 mV s−1) after 110 cycles (Fig. 13j) both indicated an enhanced interface magnetization behavior following the conversion reaction. 2.5.3 Evolution and stability of conversion reaction products of heterostructure To provide a plausible explanation for the excellent cycling stability observed in the aforementioned metal telluride heterostructure, Zhang et al. conducted an analysis of SEM, HRTEM, and EDS mapping images of ZnTe/CoTe2@NC and its individual components after 50 cycles of discharging to 0.01 V and charging to 3.0 V [45]. Interestingly, the conversion products of ZnTe/CoTe2@NC exhibited a well-preserved morphology and were uniformly distributed on the carbon networks (Fig. 14 a–d), which were covered by a solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) layer. In contrast, severe particle aggregation was observed in the ZnTe@NC and CoTe2@NC electrodes. Furthermore, the ZnTe/CoTe2@NC heterostructure demonstrated almost complete recovery in the fully de-potassiated state (Fig. 14e–h), while the single-phase counterparts experienced significant particle aggregation and structural degradation. This finding suggests that the controlled conversion and re-formation of ZnTe and CoTe2 particles within the heterostructure (Fig. 14i, j) contributed to its superior performance (Fig. 14k), as it effectively mitigated the common issue of particle aggregation encountered with single-component systems. In a word, the evolution mechanisms of the conversion reaction process during cycling were elucidated, including the role of a dual-type N-doped carbon layer in suppressing the dissolution and shuttle reaction of polytellurides, the additional interface magnetization mechanism following the conversion reaction, and the evolution and stability of conversion reaction products in heterostructures. Hence, it is evident that the conversion reaction process during cycling is complex, warranting further in-depth investigation. Interestingly, for anodes based on common transition metal chalcogenides (TMCs) such as FeSe2, CoSe2, FeS2, and NiS2, Li et al. revealed that elemental Cu from the current collector can permeate into the electrode material, displacing the transition metal and forming bonds with S or Se during cycling [102]. Taking CoS2 as an example, Yin et al. elucidated the origin of this transition behavior, which involves both chemical processes (interaction between Cu+ and resulting sodium polysulfide products) and electrochemical processes (based on the Hard-Soft-Acid-Base theory) [103]. The latest research can offer a framework for conducting an in-depth analysis to reveal the potential reaction mechanisms involving cobalt telluride and elemental copper from the current collector during the cycling process for sodium or potassium storage. 3 Other transition metal tellurides electrodes 3.1 The application in organic metal ion batteries 3.1.1 Iron telluride Iron (Fe) is abundantly available and environmentally friendly [104]. Its application in SIBs as iron ditelluride (FeTe2) was first reported by Cho et al. [105]. The research team utilized a trace amount (5 wt%) rGO to modify the Fe3O4 precursor obtained through a spray pyrolysis. Subsequently, FeTe2-rGO composites were prepared via a tellurization treatment. The FeTe2-rGO composites exhibited robust charging and discharging capabilities (257 mA h g−1 at 3 A g−1) based on a reversible conversion mechanism. In 2020, Jia et al. conducted the first study on applying FeTe2 in lithium storage [106]. They initially prepared nitrogen-doped porous carbon microspheres (NPCM) with a diameter of 650 nm, facilitating the in-situ growth of FeTe2 nanocrystallites and forming a strong interfacial contact (FeTe2@NPCM-2) (Fig. 15 a) using a hydrothermal method. The unique superstructure of FeTe2@NPCM-2 enabled a highly reversible and stable capacity of 460.7 mA h g−1 at 0.5 A g−1 after 600 cycles. In the pioneering study of FeTe2 in PIBs, Park et al. developed a composite material by combining FeTe2 with highly porous, hollow carbon nanospheres (PHCN), resulting in a yolk-void-shell configuration with FeTe2 as the yolk and FeTe2-C as the shell (Fig. 15b and c) [107]. This composite was achieved through the tellurization of PHCN infiltrated with iron nitrate nonahydrate at 400 °C. In the fully discharged state, the void and carbon shell precisely accommodated the volume expansion of FeTe2 (Fig. 15d), with the conversion products of K2Te, K5Te3, and Fe (Fig. 15e). Conversely, in the fully charged state, the yolk-void-shell structure could be fully restored (Fig. 15f), but with the formation of FeTe1.1 and Te (Fig. 15g). The heterointerface between FeTe1.1 and Te facilitated the reaction kinetics, resulting in excellent rate capability with a capacity of 126 mA h g−1 even at 10 A g−1. Interestingly, by increasing the tellurization temperature to 700 °C, a stable tetragonal FeTe phase could be formed with a simple FeTe@C configuration. Furthermore, Wang et al. synthesized tetragonal FeTe nanoparticles that were deposited on the surface of rGO using a hydrothermal method followed by an annealing process [108]. Their investigation revealed that this nanocomposite exhibited exceptional sodium and potassium storage performance. Yang et al. made a significant breakthrough by introducing FeTe2 as a cathode material for AIBs [109]. They successfully wrapped FeTe2 with GO using a facile hydrothermal method. The FeTe2@GO composite exhibited an impressive reversible capacity of 120.4 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 even after 10,000 cycles, highlighting its exceptional cycling stability. Furthermore, the energy-storage mechanism of FeTe2 was unveiled, revealing the active participation of AlCl4 −, Cl−, and Al3+ species in the intercalation and deintercalation processes throughout the battery's operation. This groundbreaking research opens new possibilities for the utilization of FeTe2 in high-performance AIBs. 3.1.2 Nickel telluride Additionally, nickel resources are abundant and cost-effective [110,111], making them valuable materials for research in organic alkali-ion batteries. Researchers have focused on studying nickel tellurides for such applications. Sun et al. successfully fabricated NiTe2/N-doped graphitic carbon nanosheets (NiTe2@NCNs) (Fig. 15h–j) for SIBs using a hexamine-based MOF as precursors [112]. A key aspect of their work involved the dominant presence of graphitic N-doped carbon matrixes (Fig. 15i), which greatly enhanced electron conductivity. This exceptional characteristic bestowed the NiTe2@NCNs with remarkable rate performance, exhibiting minimal capacity decrease even when the current density was switched from 0.1 to 10 A g−1. Additionally, the researchers employed bimetal (NiZn)-hexamine MOFs as precursors to synthesize NiTe2-ZnTe anti-blocking heterostructures (Fig. 15k), characterized by abundant interphase boundaries (Fig. 15l) [113]. Compared to pure NiTe2, incorporating ZnTe reduced the Na-ion diffusion barrier by 0.03 eV, leading to enhanced rate performance (177.2 mA h g−1 at 10 A g−1). Furthermore, Han et al. successfully synthesized porous NiTe2/N-doped carbon nanosheets (NiTe2/NC) through a sequential process involving the initial hydrothermal reaction to generate NiTe2/PDA, followed by the carbonization of polydopamine (PDA) [114]. The resulting NiTe2/NC anode for SIBs exhibited a remarkable capacity of 351 mA h g−1, even after 300 cycles at a current density of 1 A g−1. For the application of nickel telluride in AIBs, Yu et al. employed a simple hydrothermal method to synthesize NiTe nanorods [115]. They further enhanced the performance by incorporating a single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) modified separator. This approach resulted in a remarkable specific capacity of over 307 mA h g−1 after 100 cycles at 0.5 A g−1, and a high CE of approximately 98%. Moreover, the research shed light on the reaction mechanism occurring at the positive electrode, elucidating the oxidation process of NiTe to Te, Ten(AlCl4)2, and ultimately TeCl3AlCl4 during charging. Concurrently, aluminum deposition was observed at the negative electrode. Qin et al. employed a hydrothermal method to introduce a small amount of Cu2+ into Ni-MOF precursors, resulting in the formation of Ni-Cu MOF [116]. Subsequently, they prepared NiTe2@Cu microspheres through high-temperature tellurization. When utilized as a cathode material for AIBs, the reaction mechanism of NiTe2@Cu was based on the reversible intercalation/deintercalation of AlCl4 −, accompanied by changes in the valence state of Te. Furthermore, the NiTe2@Cu cathode demonstrated excellent cycling stability, maintaining a capacity of 214 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.2 A g−1. 3.1.3 Zinc telluride Compared to other transition metals (e.g., Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, etc.), zinc (Zn) can form an alloy with Li to produce Li x Zn [117–119]. Therefore, the ZnTe anode material exhibits a low discharging voltage platform and a high initial capacity. However, it may undergo significant volume variations during cycling, leading to a rapid decline in capacity [120]. In a study by Seo et al., ZnTe/C nanocomposites were first fabricated using high-energy mechanical milling [121]. This approach resulted in the formation of ZnTe nanocrystallites (5–10 nm) uniformly embedded in an amorphous carbon matrix, thereby exhibiting satisfactory lithium storage capability. Subsequently, Nguyen et al. introduced a binary hybrid conductive buffering matrix (TiO2-C and TiC-C) by employing high-energy mechanical milling of acetylene black and a pre-annealed mixture (ZnO-Te-Ti and Zn-Te-Ti) [122,123]. Remarkably, this composite material demonstrated superior performance compared to using a single TiO2 or amorphous carbon buffering matrix. Through implementing morphology engineering techniques, Zhang et al. successfully synthesized ZnTe@N-doped carbon nanowires (ZnTe@C) (Fig. 15m) using a facile ion-exchange process followed by carbonization [124]. The obtained ZnTe@C material exhibits exceptional properties, making it a promising candidate for LIBs and SIBs. It boasts several advantages, including superior tap density, excellent structural stability, impressive rate capability, high specific capacity, substantial volumetric capacity, and enhanced safety. Regarding its performance in Li-ion storage, ZnTe@C demonstrates a stable and impressive gravimetric capacity of 710 mA h−1 (with a volumetric capacity of 575 mA h cm−3) at 0.5 A g−1 after 200 cycles. Furthermore, it exhibits a high-rate capability, delivering a gravimetric capacity of 618 mA h g−1 and a volumetric capacity of 501 mA h cm−3 at 2 A g−1. 3.1.4 Copper telluride The composition and morphology of copper telluride are highly complex [127]. And the phases can be orthorhombic CuTe, hexagonal Cu2Te, Cu3Te4, Cu7Te5, and nonstoichiometric Cu2– x Te, etc. Han et al. observed that the morphology of copper telluride nanostructures can exhibit diverse forms, such as nanocubes, nanoparticles, and nanosheets, depending on the specific solvothermal parameters employed [128]. Notably, they found that the nanosheet configuration of Cu2− x Te displayed the most exceptional lithium storage capability among these various morphologies. Subsequently, Yu et al. successfully synthesized Cu1.75Te nanowires coated with PDA-derived carbon through an in situ conversion, polymerization, and subsequent heat treatment process [129]. When employed as anodes for both LIBs and SIBs, the modified Cu1.75Te nanowires exhibited impressive discharge capacities of 673.3 mA h−1 (after 60 cycles) and 177.5 mA h−1 (after 500 cycles), respectively, at a current density of 100 mA g−1. Furthermore, Kushwah et al. successfully synthesized orthorhombic Cu2.86Te2 nano blocks and faceted nanocrystals of Cu31Te24 through the thermolysis and pyrolysis of a single-source molecular precursor ([CuTeC5H3(Me-5)N]4), respectively [130]. These phases have expanded the range of copper telluride materials available. Moreover, in terms of lithium storage, Cu31Te24 exhibited superior performance compared to Cu2.86Te2. Monolayer copper telluride (ML-CuTe) can be obtained by exfoliating bulk CuTe and exhibits remarkable stability, as evidenced by DFT calculations and force-field molecular dynamics simulations. Ling et al. calculated an open-circuit voltage range of 0.12–0.32 V, Na+ diffusion energy barriers of 0.31–0.72 eV, and a specific capacity of 280 mA h mol−1 for ML-CuTe. These findings suggest ML-CuTe's potential as a competitive anode material for s SIBs [131]. Recently, Chang et al. obtained copper telluride nanotubes with various compositions, including Cu0.5Te, Cu1.0Te, Cu1.5Te, and Cu2Te, and investigated their potassium storage performance [132]. At a low current density (50 mA g−1), Cu1.0Te, Cu1.5Te, and Cu2Te nanotubes all exhibit a reversible specific capacity of 300 mA h g−1 during the first 5 cycles, while Cu0.5Te exhibits a reversible specific capacity of 150 mA h g−1. This lower capacity is likely due to insufficient copper to fully activate the K-Te transformation reaction. In later cycles, as the copper content increases, the capacity of copper telluride nanotubes also increases, indicating enhanced electrochemical performance with higher copper content. However, as the current density rises, nanotubes with more copper exhibit slower capacity reduction, likely due to enhanced conductivity from increased copper precipitation during the conversion reaction. Furthermore, Cu7Te4 nanowire structures were prepared to study the effect of morphology on electrochemical performance. It is found that the capacity at higher current densities (0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 3, and 5 A g−1) is lower than that of Cu2Te nanotubes, demonstrating the superiority of the hollow morphology of nanotubes, which can ensure the full penetration of the electrolyte and buffer the volume expansion during cycles. In summary, Cu2Te nanotubes deliver excellent electrochemical performance due to the full potassium ion reaction sites, enhanced K-Te conversion kinetics, and conductivity. In terms of its application in AIBs, Wu et al. initially explored the aluminum storage performance and reaction mechanism of rod-shaped Cu1.81Te, which was synthesized using a straightforward hydrothermal method [133]. The study revealed that the Cu1.81Te cathode exhibited reversible intercalation and de-intercalation reactions with Al3+ ions during cycling. Notably, the cathode demonstrated an initial discharge capacity of 144 mA h g−1 at a current density of 40 mA g−1. 3.1.5 Molybdenum telluride Hexagonal MoTe2 (2H phase) is a layered material with weak Van der Waals interaction between layers, which has attracted significant interest in alkali metal ion batteries [134–136]. Panda et al. reported the synthesis of bulk layered MoTe2 single crystals through a facile solid-state reaction without any modification [137]. These crystals exhibited excellent sodium storage ability, with a capacity of 270 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles at 1 A g−1 and 216 mA h g−1 at 5 A g−1, based on the initial intercalation and subsequent conversion processes. Subsequently, Panda et al. extended their investigation to applying this material in LIBs, where they observed similarly excellent electrochemical performance based on a similar reaction mechanism [138]. However, Wu et al. discovered that sub-millimeter scale single-crystal 2H MoTe2 exhibited poor cycling stability when applied in PIBs [139]. They revealed that the failure originated from the irreversible recovery of 2H-MoTe2 after cycling but noted a reversible conversion among K2Te3-KTe-K5Te3. The tellurization of C–MoO x precursors under reducing or inert atmospheres is a widely adopted method for preparing MoTe2 and carbon composites. These precursors can exist as microspheres or self-assembled MoTe2 hierarchical nanoflowers. Cho et al. successfully synthesized two distinct composites by manipulating the tellurization temperatures of C–MoO x microspheres [140]. At 450 °C, MoTe2 nanocrystals are uniformly dispersed within the carbon microspheres. However, at 600 °C, the MoTe2 nanocrystals undergo Ostwald ripening and migrate to the surface, forming a shell around the microspheres (C@MoTe2). Both composite types exhibit superior sodium storage performance compared to bare MoTe2. Notably, the C@MoTe2 composite demonstrates remarkable discharge capacities, reaching 286 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1 after 200 cycles. Furthermore, Bai et al. utilized a Mo-PDA flower as a precursor to fabricate a nanoflower-like MoTe2/C anode material (Fig. 15n) for SIBs [125]. The unique 3D hierarchical network effectively suppresses volume expansion and exposes many active sites, enabling robust cycling performance. After 3000 cycles, the material exhibits a remarkable capacity of 190 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1. Moreover, Liang et al. successfully synthesized 3D porous carbon networks (3DPCN) that confine MoTe2 nanosheets (Fig. 15o), exhibiting excellent sodium storage capability [126]. This was achieved by employing a NaCl-assisted strategy. The presence of NaCl facilitated the synthesis of highly crystalline MoTe2 with an ideal stoichiometric ratio under mild reaction conditions. This effect was attributed to the reduced adsorption energy of H2Te on MoS2 and the easy breakoff of the Te–H bond. The unique strategy enabled the scalable and cost-effective fabrication of MoTe2/carbon composites, which can be extended to synthesize other metallic telluride/carbon composites. Compared to the 2H phase, the 1T′ phase of MoTe2 exhibits a monoclinic structure and demonstrates semimetallic properties with higher carrier mobility and a narrow band gap of only 60 meV. However, synthesizing a pure 1T′-MoTe2 is challenging due to the minute energy difference between the 2H and 1T′ phases, resulting in limited research on this topic. Ma et al. investigated the potential application of 1T′-MoTe2 as an electrode material in LIBs [141]. They successfully synthesized MoTe2 nanosheets with native tellurium defects encapsulated by a few layers of graphene (MoTe2/FLG) using mechanical milling. Furthermore, they calculated a low diffusion barrier of 0.18 eV for Li-ions, facilitating efficient Li+ insertion/extraction processes and enabling excellent rate capability (334.5 mA h g−1 at 2 A g−1). In 2022, Panda fully exploited the highly conductive characteristics of 1T′-MoTe2 and developed a practical electrode configuration without carbonaceous additives, making practical applications feasible [142]. Chevrel phase Mo6Te8 nanoparticles doped with carbon and nitrogen (Mo6Te8@C/N) were initially reported by Leng et al. These Mo6Te8@C/N nanoparticles were skillfully synthesized through a high-temperature solid reaction between Mo6Te8 and dopamine [143]. Incorporating C/N atoms into the Mo6Te8 structure occurs through adsorption in the vacancies or lattice gaps, resulting in an expanded crystal lattice and enhanced conductivity. This modification facilitates the smoother diffusion of lithium ions. As a result, the Mo6Te8@C/N composite exhibits exceptional cycling stability, demonstrating a maximum capacity of 812.13 and 436 mA h g−1 at 0.1 and 1 A g−1, respectively. A series of modified transition metal tellurides as electrode materials for organic metal ion batteries, including iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, and molybdenum telluride, are summarized above. Electrochemical performances of reported TMTs applied in organic metal ion batteries is summarized in Table S1. It can be noticed that their effective modification strategies are also realized by composite and defect engineering. Hydrothermal and chemical vapor deposition methods used in cobalt telluride are also the most common methods for synthesizing these composites with various carbon or defects. In addition, ion-exchange and mechanical balling can also be used as alternative methods. Like the many components of cobalt telluride, these transition metal tellurides exist in various forms such as FeTe2, FeTe1.1, FeTe, NiTe2, NiTe, Cu2Te, Cu3Te4, Cu7Te5, Cu2– x Te, 2H MoTe2, 1T′ MoTe2, Chevrel Mo6Te8. The polymorphic forms of these transition metal tellurides make them ideal models for an in-depth study of the effect of homogeneous interfaces on ion transport and structural stability. On the other hand, their application in AIBs is still immature. More extensive use of in situ characterization methods is needed to elucidate the reaction mechanisms of AIBs, and further efforts can be devoted to modify the reported TMTs electrodes or to explore new TMTs cathodes with high capacity, high stability, and fast charging capabilities. 3.2 Typical transition metal tellurides applied in Li-S batteries Doping presents an effective approach for adjusting the concentration of vacancies in the crystal structure by occupying the vacant sites [144]. In their pioneering work, Yao et al. synthesized NiTe2 with abundant Te vacancies distributed on maize-straw carbon nanosheets (MSC/NiTe2− x ) (Fig. 16 a, b) by tellurizing the precursors at 600 °C under an Ar/H2 reducing atmosphere [145]. Subsequently, hetero P-atoms were introduced to fill the Te vacancies, resulting in the formation of MSC/P ⊂ NiTe2− x . For a clear observation of the atomic vacancy structures, spherical-aberration-corrected HADDF-STEM (Fig. 16c) can be employed. Ideally, the Ni and Te atomic columns should exhibit regular arrangement with a uniform intensity profile. However, in the case of NiTe2− x , several missing Te atoms were observed, indicating the presence of significant Te vacancies. Upon P doping (Fig. 16d), only a few missing Te atoms were detectable, suggesting the compensation of Te vacancies. Furthermore, X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectra (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure spectra (EXAFS) serve as effective tools for characterizing the vacancy structure. In comparison to the considerable negative shift in the Ni K-edge and the noticeable decrease in peak intensity of the Ni-Te bond in NiTe2− x , P ⊂ NiTe2− x closely approaches the edge of NiTe2 while maintaining a similar peak intensity to that of NiTe2 (Fig. 16e, f). These results strongly suggest that P doping occupies the Te vacancy sites. The distinct intensity difference in the oscillation amplitude of NiTe2− x and P ⊂ NiTe2− x further supports this mechanism (Fig. 16g). DFT calculations revealed that MSC/P ⊂ NiTe2− x exhibits the strongest chemical adsorption (Fig. 16h) of LiPSs through forming S-Ni and Li–Te bonds, effectively mitigating the shuttle effect. This finding is further supported by in situ Raman and ex-situ X-ray absorption spectra. As a result, MSC/P ⊂ NiTe2− x -based cells demonstrate excellent rate performance, achieving a capacity of 726 mA h g−1 at 6 C, as well as remarkable cyclability, maintaining a capacity of 637 mA h g−1 at 4 C over 1800 cycles. For MoTe2, it exists in three phases: 2H, 1T, and 1T′ phases. Wei successfully synthesized 2H-MoTe2@GO composites utilizing an ultra-fast microwave method with only 90 s [146]. The resulting composites demonstrated exceptional cycle stability and rate performance when employed as the cathode material in Li-S batteries, owing to the chemical adsorption and electrocatalytic capabilities of 2H-MoTe2 towards LiPSs. Yu et al. conducted DFT calculations and found that 1T′-MoTe2 exhibits the highest conductivity with a concentrated DOS near the Fermi level [52]. This structure is relatively stable, with a slight energy difference of only 0.04 eV molecule–1compared to 2H-MoTe2. In their study, they synthesized 1T′-MoTe2 quantum dots (less than 3 nm) and uniformly attached them to 3D GO (MTQ@3DG) (Fig. 16i, j), acting as the host material for Li-S batteries. As anticipated, MTQ@3DG/S demonstrated outstanding performance, achieving a high specific capacity of 1310.1 mA h g−1 at 0.2 C and robust cycling stability, exhibiting a capacity fade rate of only 0.026% per cycle over 600 cycles at 1 C. The underlying mechanism was analyzed through DFT calculations. Compared to GO, which can only bind with Li, the 1T′-MoTe2 monolayer can bind with both S and Li atoms, resulting in significantly higher adsorption energy for LiPSs entrapment (Fig. 16k). This suppresses the shuttling effect of LiPSs in the system. Moreover, the rate-limiting step for the conversion of LiPSs to Li2S requires an energy barrier (Fig. 16l, m) of 0.97 eV, lower than that of GO (1.07 eV), indicating the high catalytic effect of 1T′-MoTe2 quantum dots. The effective suppression of LiPSs shuttling is further supported by in situ Raman analysis (Fig. 16n, o). In contrast to the distinct signals of S8 2–, S6 2–, or S4 2– detected in graphene/S, these signals are nearly absent in MTQ@3DG/S. Lin et al. conducted the synthesis of single-crystalline 1T'-MoTe2 nanosheets as an electrocatalyst for Li-S batteries using a combination of chemical vapor transport, electrochemical intercalation, and sonication processes [147]. The adsorption energy of LiPSs on 1T'-MoTe2 was lower than GO layers, particularly for Li2S2/Li2S adsorption (Fig. 17 a). Wavefunction analysis revealed notable differences in the interactions. Specifically, the interactions between 1T'-MoTe2 and Li2S2/Li2S were characterized by two Te-S two-center localized molecular orbitals (LMOs) and one Te-S two-center LMO (Fig. 17b). Considering the spatial orientation of the LMOs and the electron configuration of Te and S atoms, it can be inferred that the strong adsorption/conversion of Li2S2/Li2S molecules on the 1T'-MoTe2 surface is attributed to the interaction between Te p and S p orbitals. Consequently, the 1T'-MoTe2 nanosheets exhibit remarkable catalytic activity, resulting in enhanced rate capability and cycling stability in Li-S batteries. Moreover, 1T'-MoTe2 not only serves as an inhibitor of the polysulfide shuttle effect but also effectively suppresses the growth of Li dendrites. He et al. successfully achieved the in situ growth of 1T'-MoTe2 nanosheets on carbon nanotubes (MoTe2-CNT) (Fig. 17c) using a facile hydrothermal method [148]. By loading lithium metal onto MoTe2-CNT (MoTe2-CNT/Li), MoTe2 can undergo in situ conversion to Li2Te, which exhibits high ionic conductivity, and metallic Mo, providing a favorable nucleation site for uniform lithium growth. Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) analysis revealed a consistent distribution of secondary-ion species (Li−, C−, Mo−, and LiTe−) throughout the sputter period (Fig. 17d, e), indicating the uniform distribution of Li metal within the MoTe2-CNT framework. Additionally, when the MoTe2-CNT/Li anode was paired with a S/MoTe2-CNT cathode in full coin cells, a thin and stable SEI composed of lithium thiotellurate (Li2TeS3) could be formed on the MoTe2-CNT/Li anode. This formation was confirmed through ToF-SIMS analysis (Fig. 17f, g) of the SEI on MoTe2-CNT/Li after 50 cycles. The SEI further enhanced the stability of Li deposition and significantly extended the cycle life of the full coin cells, demonstrating a high areal capacity of 7.6 mA h cm−2 with 75% capacity retention after 500 cycles and a negative to positive electrode capacity ratio of approximately 2.5.
