Na-S batteries, which operate similarly to Li-S batteries but utilize abundant sodium resources, have garnered significant attention in energy storage systems. However, the notorious polysulfide shuttling effect remains a challenge in Na-S batteries. Recently, MoTe2 has emerged as a promising catalyst to address this issue in Na-S batteries. Gao et al. successfully synthesized 3D flower-like architectures of MoTe2 to mitigate the shuttling of sodium polysulfide with the strong chemical adsorption of polar MoTe2 and the physical barrier provided by its structure [149]. He et al. proposed the concept of an intercalation-conversion hybrid cathode for Na-S batteries. They vertically grew intercalative-type MoTe2 nanosheets on graphene flakes (MTG) and combined them with conversion-type S. This innovative hybrid cathode design facilitates the formation of an excellent short-range ion conduction pathway for sulfur redox reactions during the sodiation/desodiation process of MTG [150]. In the application in Li-S batteries, MoTe2, particularly 1T'-MoTe2, stands out among transition metal tellurides. Extensive research indicates that MoTe2 mitigates the shuttle effect of LiPSs by enhancing their adsorption energy and effectively hinders the formation of lithium dendrites. Furthermore, it shows promise as a catalyst in addressing the polysulfide shuttle phenomenon in emerging Na-S batteries. Electrochemical performances of TMTs applied in Li-S batteries are summarized in Table S2. Apart from cobalt telluride, molybdenum telluride, and nickel telluride, the utilization of other TMTs in Li-S batteries remains unexplored. Hence, future endeavors should focus on uncovering and advancing the application of novel TMTs in both Li-S and Na-S battery systems. 3.3 Typical transition metal tellurides applied in aqueous metal ion batteries Cu2Te demonstrates promise as an anode material for AZIBs due to its excellent electronic conductivity and low discharge potential. Li et al. employed DFT calculations to reveal the electronic structure and optimal migration path of Cu2Te and its defect state [151]. Introduction of cation vacancies in Cu2Te can distort the symmetrical electron density distributions (Fig. 18 a, b), resulting in slightly positive and negative charged center areas and strongly positive charged Cu-rich areas away from the center. These variations in electronic structure likely contribute to differences in electrochemical activity. Additionally, Cu2– x Te exhibits smaller diffusion barriers for Zn2+, particularly along paths 5, 6, and 8 (Fig. 18c, f), which have larger tunnel sizes. Furthermore, the E ads of Zn2+ along these optimal paths in Cu2– x Te are weaker (Fig. 18g, h), facilitating the extraction of Zn2+. These favorable diffusion paths make Cu2– x Te a competitive anode material for Zn-ion batteries. They prepared sheet-like Cu2− x Te anodes (Fig. 18i) through in situ electrochemical activation and observed an ultraflat discharge plateau at 0.2 V, contributing to 86% of the total capacity. The flat plateaus were maintained under different current densities, demonstrating exceptional rate performance (Fig. 18j, k). Furthermore, Cu2– x Te exhibited a typical insertion and conversion reaction mechanism. Moreover, the researchers synthesised Cu7Te4 (Fig. 18l) via a vacuum solid–liquid reaction [152]. Similar to Cu2Te, this novel phase exhibits a low long discharge plateau at 0.2 V and demonstrates exceptional fast-charging capacity (Fig. 18m, n). Notably, Cu7Te4 outperforms the Cu2– x Te electrode with an initial discharge capacity of 216 mA h g−1, surpassing the 158 mAh g−1 of Cu2– x Te. These findings highlight Cu7Te4 as a stable anode material with a high capacity for AZIBs. Du et al. reported that the storage of Zn2+ between MoTe2 bulk layers is energetically favorable, as evidenced by the calculated negative E ads (−0.6 eV) [153]. Moreover, the introduction of tellurium vacancies (TVs) in MoTe2 creates additional active sites for Zn2+ storage, exhibiting an even more negative E ads of −1.7 eV (Fig. 19 a). This modification not only enhances Zn2+ storage but also reduces the diffusion energy barrier by providing additional migration paths within the TVs (Fig. 19b). To validate the practical implications of these findings, the researchers successfully synthesized MoTe1.7 with a high density of TVs using laser radiation. The resulting electrode exhibited a remarkable triple capacity of 338 mA h g−1 compared to the MoTe2 electrode, accompanied by an 18% improvement in capacity retention (Fig. 19c). Furthermore, the charge density difference images of MoTe2− x Zn y revealed strong chemical interactions between Zn and Te, indicating the potential involvement of a conversion reaction mechanism. In-situ XRD measurements (Fig. 19d) and ex-situ Zn 2p spectra verified the reversible formation and dissociation of ZnTe during cycling. Additionally, ex-situ Mo 3d spectra provided valuable insights into the role of redox centers, aligning with the reaction mechanism predicted by theoretical calculations. Furthermore, it has been discovered that titanium telluride (TiTe2) can serve as a suitable anode material for AZIBs. Du et al. conducted a study in which they revealed the favorable storage of Zn2+ ions in the interlayer of TiTe2, supported by DFT calculations that showed a negative E ads of −1.7 eV (Fig. 19e). Additionally, analysis of the DOS (Fig. 19f) near the Fermi level indicated that the Ti state predominantly contributes to the active electron provision. The researchers successfully synthesized a layered TiTe2 sample using a one-step vacuum sintering technique and observed its exceptional rate capabilities (Fig. 19g), achieving a capacity of 191 mA h g−1 at 1.0 A g−1 [154]. Moreover, the reversible two-electron conversion reaction of Ti2+/Ti4+ was confirmed through in-situ XRD and ex-situ XANES spectra, providing further evidence for the electrochemical behavior of TiTe2 as an anode material in AZIBs. Li et al. synthesized zinc telluride nanowires (ZnTe NWs) using an ion exchange method for aqueous Zn batteries [155]. It was observed that the pure ZnTe NWs exhibited significant capacity decay due to the dissolution of the ZnTe electrode. However, by applying a carbon coating on the surface of ZnTe NWs (Fig. 20 a, b), the electrode demonstrated impressive fast charging capability with a capacity of 309 mA h g−1 at 1 A g−1, and stable capacity of 380 mA h g−1 after 80 cycles at 0.1 A g−1 (Fig. 20c). This enhancement in performance can be attributed to the suppression of intermediate dissolution, thereby preventing the deposition of Te and ZnTe on the anode surface. Additionally, the authors elucidated the origin of the ultra-high theoretical capacity, which can be explained by a reversible two-step conversion mechanism (Fig. 20d) involving a six-electron transfer from ZnTe to Te and Te to TeO2. Ex situ XRD, XPS, and TEM analyses supported this mechanism. Furthermore, ZnTe can be employed as a zincophilic artificial layer to suppress dendrite growth and parasitic reactions effectively. Wang et al. successfully fabricated a 3D-interconnected porous ZnTe layer on the Zn matrix (ZnTe@Zn) using a straightforward electrodeposition process followed by a vapor–solid reaction [156]. The ZnTe layer promotes uniform Zn deposition, as evidenced by the simulated uniform spatial distribution of charge regions and Zn2+ along the Zn electrode surface (Fig. 20e). The well-preserved porous surface (Fig. 20f) after 50 cycles further substantiates its efficient suppression of dendrite growth. Additionally, the strong binding energy (Fig. 20g) between Te atoms and (002) planes facilitates the growth of the dendrite-resistant (002) plane of Zn. Consequently, the ZnTe@Zn electrode exhibits promising prospects in AZIBs due to its exceptional stability, durability, and minimal voltage hysteresis. Currently, research on the application of TMTs as anode materials in AZIBs is limited. Electrochemical performances of TMTs applied in AZIBs are summarized in Table S3. Only copper telluride (Cu2Te, Cu7Te4), molybdenum telluride, titanium telluride, and zinc telluride have been reported. Copper telluride exhibits a notable advantage with a low discharge plateau at 0.2 V. DFT studies reveal the negative E ads of MoTe2 and TiTe2 to Zn2+, experimentally supporting their potential as promising anode materials for AZIBs. Additionally, the presence of cation vacancies in Cu2Te and Te vacancies in MoTe2 can reduce the diffusion barriers of Zn2+, thus enhancing their fast charging capability. Furthermore, incorporating carbon into ZnTe composites can mitigate the dissolution of intermediates, thereby improving cycling stability. Future research efforts should focus on exploring novel TMTs and optimizing electrode properties through morphology, composite, and defect engineering. 4 Conclusions and future prospects This comprehensive review thoroughly analyses the utilization of modified cobalt telluride-based electrodes in various energy storage systems, including organic alkali metal ion batteries, Li-S batteries, and Li-Te batteries. The main modification strategies, defect engineering (Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces), composite engineering, and phase engineering are summarized. TMTs with vacancies alter the electronic structure, expose more active sites, enhance the adsorption energy of alkali metal ions or polysulfides, and reduce diffusion energy barriers, enabling high capacity and fast charging capability. Heterointerfaces between TMTs with different work functions generate an inherent electric field directed towards the TMT with the higher work functions, further enhancing the reaction dynamics. Conversely, homogeneous interfaces formed in polymorphic materials offer better compatibility due to smaller lattice mismatches. Compared to the vacancy structure, the interface is relatively stable, ensuring the reversibility of the reactions to a certain extent. To maintain high capacity after extended cycles, researchers ingeniously control the concentration of defects and combine them with elastic Mxene or various carbon matrices, establishing a strong interaction between TMTs and matrix materials, resulting in robust structural stability. Compared to defect engineering, research on composite engineering is considerably more extensive. Carbon is commonly used as a composite material due to its high conductivity and toughness, with various forms such as derived carbon from precursors (ZIF-67, PDA, polyacrylonitrile), GO, rGO, and CNTs. The buffered effect becomes more pronounced with the combination of different carbon forms. Moreover, the interaction between the carbon matrix and TMTs has also been revealed, which can further enhance the structure stability and transport of electrons/ions. Regarding phase engineering, it has been reported that o-CoTe2 exhibits a better catalytic role in suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs compared to h-CoTe2. Nonetheless, cobalt telluride can manifest in diverse compositions (CoTe2, CoTe, Co1+δTe) and crystal structures (hexagonal, orthorhombic, and rhombohedral). Hence, future endeavors could focus on comparative analyses of these cobalt tellurides, elucidating their respective catalytic mechanisms and identifying the optimal host materials. A series of modified transition metal tellurides as electrode materials for rechargeable ions batteries, including iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, and molybdenum telluride, are also summarized. It can be noticed that their effective modification strategies are also realized by composite and defect engineering. Like the many components of cobalt telluride, these transition metal tellurides exist in various forms such as FeTe2, FeTe1.1, FeTe, NiTe2, NiTe, Cu2Te, Cu3Te4, Cu7Te5, Cu2– x Te, 2H MoTe2, 1T′ MoTe2, Chevrel Mo6Te8. The polymorphic forms of these transition metal tellurides make them ideal models for an in-depth study of the effect of homogeneous interfaces on ion transport and structural stability. On the other hand, their application in AIBs is still immature, more extensive use of in situ characterization methods is needed to elucidate the reaction mechanisms of AIBs, and further efforts can be devoted to modify the reported TMTs electrodes or to explore new TMTs cathodes with high capacity, high stability, and fast charging capabilities. The development direction and prospects of TMTs are summarized in Fig. 21 , and the specific contents are as follows. (1) The defect engineering focuses on the composite of TMTs, such as their combination with MXene and various nitrogen-doped carbon materials, which may not facilitate the fabrication of electrodes with high energy density. Furthermore, the precise impact of defect engineering on structural stability throughout cycles remains to be accurately delineated. Hence, there is a pressing need to obtain pure TMTs, which can also find applications in other domains, including water splitting, dye-sensitized solar cells, and oxygen reduction reactions. (2) Compared to defect engineering, research on composite engineering is considerably more extensive. However, the depth of research in composite engineering remains insufficient. In the future, single doping of elements such as B, F, P, S, or multiple doping in carbon can be pursued to further enhance the electrochemical performance of composites. Additionally, finite element analysis and DFT calculations need to be incorporated to aid in the design of electrodes and analyze the underlying reaction mechanisms. For instance, the carbon buffer effects on strain/stress during cycles can be intuitively reflected through Comsol simulations, and the critical role of doping atoms in carbon on intermediate or final reaction products, such as K5Te3, K2Te, Na2Te, can be elucidated through DFT calculations. (3) Early studies were dedicated to synthesizing and modifying TMTs electrodes, aiming to achieve outstanding electrochemical performance and unravelling their reaction mechanism through initial charge/discharge process investigations. However, there is a lack of comprehensive analysis regarding the profound impact of microstructure and component evolution during cycling on their prolonged cycle life. In the future, the evolutive and specific reaction mechanism of TMTs for sodium or potassium storage during cycling should be elucidated by various experimental and theoretical analyses, which can refer to the research of TMCs. For example, the potential reaction mechanisms involving cobalt telluride and elemental copper from the current collector during the cycling process for sodium or potassium storage deserve to investigate. (4) In the application of Li-S batteries, apart from cobalt telluride, molybdenum telluride, and nickel telluride, the utilization of other TMTs in Li-S batteries remains unexplored. Hence, future endeavors should focus on uncovering and advancing the application of novel TMTs in Li-S and emerging Na-S batteries. In addition, research on the application of TMTs as anode materials in AZIBs is also limited. Only copper telluride (Cu2Te, Cu7Te4), molybdenum telluride, titanium telluride, and zinc telluride have been reported. Future research efforts should focus on exploring novel TMTs and optimizing electrode properties through morphology, composite, and defect engineering. (5) The practical utilization of high-capacity electrodes with both high gravimetric and volumetric energy density has garnered significant attention for next-generation rechargeable batteries. However, the current summarized modification strategy is predominantly focused on nano and/or void engineering, which undermines the inherent advantages of high-density TMTs and hampers their commercial viability due to low tap density. Materials with low tap density necessitate increased particle volume to achieve the desired areal capacity, resulting in larger cell volumes that limit the feasibility of achieving high volumetric energy density. Conversely, enlarging particle size and densifying particles can enhance tap density and reduce the specific surface area, thus facilitating high volumetric capacity with excellent initial CE. Therefore, exploiting nonporous and micron-sized TMTs becomes essential for ensuring the practical feasibility of advanced rechargeable batteries. (6) In recent years, high-entropy materials have emerged as highly promising anode materials for rechargeable batteries. These materials are characterized by the coexistence of multiple principal elements in a single phase, offering unique advantages such as the entropy stabilization effect and cocktail effect. Notably, high-entropy transition metal oxides anodes, including rocksalt-type MO (M = Co, Cu, Mg, Ni, and Zn), and M3O4 (M = Fe, Cu, Ni, Cr, and Mn), as well as high-entropy transition metal sulfides (HE-TMSs) anodes, including pyrite MS2 (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, Cu, Cr, and Ti), and orthorhombic MS (M = Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, and Cr), have demonstrated remarkable energy storage capabilities in LIBs and SIBs. Additionally, the utilization of high-entropy MXene mediators has shown great promise in Li-S batteries. Building upon these research findings and employing advanced machine learning methods, it is possible to screen high-entropy TMTs with optimal compositions for energy storage and conversion applications. (7) To achieve rechargeable batteries with high energy density, it is crucial to consider using materials with larger particle sizes and designing thick electrodes. However, conventional thick electrodes with high tortuosity introduce longer ion/electron transport paths and hinder the effective utilization of active sites, resulting in reduced fast charging capability and capacity. One practical approach is to design thick electrodes with low tortuosity, incorporating an aligned and open pore structure through techniques such as ice-templating, solvent evaporation, and phase inversion. This design strategy reduces concentration polarization and accelerates reaction kinetics, enhancing battery performance. Furthermore, a downward gradient design of active materials within the thick electrode can address heterogeneous mass transport along the thickness direction. This design minimizes polarization and improves the utilization of active materials. The external magnetic field-assisted method can be utilized to achieve this electrode structure, leveraging the unique magnetic properties of certain TMTs such as cobalt telluride, iron telluride, and nickel telluride. Huilin Fan is currently a Ph.D. candidate under the supervision of Prof. Yanguo Liu at Northeast University. She focuses on the applications of metal chalcogenides, including metal sulfide, selenide, and telluride, in energy storage and conversion. Her research also includes the development of alkali metal ion batteries with ultra-fast charging capabilities by studying the effect of interface interactions (homogeneous interfaces and heterogeneous interfaces) on ion and electron transport. Yuan Wang (Helena) is a senior lecturer and ARC-DECRA Fellow at the Department of Chemical Engineering at the University of Melbourne. She is leader of the Renewable Resources & Sustainability (R2S) group. Helena completed her Ph.D. in chemical engineering at the University of New South Wales (UNSW) in 2018. She held prestigious fellowships: the Alfred Deakin Research Fellowship-2022 at Deakin University and the International Hydrogen Research Fellowship-2023 at the National University of Singapore. She was also a DAAD Visiting Scholar at the Fritz Haber Institute of Max Planck-Berlin (2018). Her research focuses on green hydrogen production, carbon dioxide conversion and utilization, metal recovery and recycling, and circular economy. Hamidreza Arandiyan is a leader of Critical Minerals for Clean Energy (CMCE) research group and has an academic tenure in Applied Chemistry and Environmental Science at RMIT University. He completed his Ph.D. from the School of Environment at Tsinghua University in 2014. He received a Vice-Chancellor's Research Fellowship from the University of New South Wales at the School of Chemical Engineering in 2015. He held a University of Sydney Senior VC Fellowship in the School of Chemistry in 2018. He is a Fellow of the Royal Society of Chemistry (FRSC). His research focuses on resource recovery for environmental remediation and energy applications. Zongping Shao is a professor of chemical engineering at Curtin University, Australia and Nanjing Tech University, China. He obtained his Ph.D. from Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, China in 2000. He worked as a visiting scholar at the Institut de Researches sur la Catalyse, CNRS, France and as a postdoctoral research fellow at the California Institute of Technology, USA, from 2000 to 2005. His research interests include solid oxide fuel cells, lithium-ion batteries, supercapacitors, and low-temperature energy-conversion devices. He has been recognised as a Highly Cited Researcher in the Energy section by Elsevier since 2015. He has also been selected as a World Highly Cited Researcher by (Thomson Reuters) Clairvate Analytics for 2014, 2017, 2018, and 2019. Hongyu Sun received his Ph.D. degree from the State Key Laboratory of Metastable Materials Science and Technology, Yanshan University in 2010. He then worked in the Department of Materials Science and Engineering (2010-2012), Beijing National Centre for Electron Microscopy (2012–2015), at Tsinghua University (with Prof. Jing Zhu), Department of Micro- and Nanotechnology at the Technical University of Denmark (2015–2018, with Prof. Kristian Mølhave). He is a senior scientist at DENSsolution B.V. He received the Robert P. Apkarian Award (Physical Sciences, 2018) from the Microscopy Society of America. He is a guest professor at Northeastern University (Qinhuangdao campus). He received the Robert P. Apkarian Award (Physical Sciences, 2018) from the Microscopy Society of America. His research interests include energy storage and conversion, environmental cell electron microscopy, and microfabrication. Yanguo Liu received his Ph.D. in material physics and chemistry from Yanshan University in 2009. He is currently a professor at Northeast University and the director of the Science and Technology Department at Northeastern University at Qinghuangdao. He is the recipient of the first and third prizes of provincial and ministerial natural science and the second prize of municipal technological progress. He has hosted the National Natural Science Foundation of China and the Natural Science Foundation of Liaoning Province. His research interests include functional nanostructures and energy science.

coredata.dc:description: Metal (Li, Na, K, Al)-ion batteries and lithium-sulfur and lithium-tellurium batteries are gaining recognition for their eco-friendly characteristics, substantial energy density, and sustainable attributes. However, the overall performance of rechargeable batteries heavily depends on their electrode materials. Transition metal tellurides have recently gained significant attention due to their high electrical conductivity and density. Cobalt telluride has received the most extensive research due to its catalytic activity, unique magnetic properties, and diverse composition and crystal structure. Nevertheless, its limited conductivity and significant volume variation contribute to electrode structural deterioration and rapid capacity decline. This review comprehensively summarizes recent advances in rational design and synthesis of modified cobalt telluride-based electrodes, encompassing defect engineering (Te vacancies, cation vacancies, heterointerfaces, and homogeneous interfaces) and composite engineering (derived carbon from precursors, carbon fibers, Mxene, graphene nanosheets, etc.). Particularly, the intricate evolution mechanisms of the conversion reaction process during cycling are elucidated. Furthermore, these modified strategies applied to other transitional metal tellurides, such as iron telluride, nickel telluride, zinc telluride, copper telluride, molybdenum telluride, etc., are also thoroughly summarized. Additionally, their application extends to emerging aqueous zinc-ion batteries. Finally, potential challenges and prospects are discussed to further propel the development of transition metal tellurides electrode materials for next-generation rechargeable batteries.
